name: OSM: create and extract geospatial data
summary: Learn how to contribute geographical data to OpenStreetMap, and use the database in QGIS.
details:
OpenStreetMap (OSM) is an open-licence spatial database.

In this hands-on workshop, you will learn how to:

  • Digitise geographical data into the OSM database
  • Use an editor directly from the browser
  • Contribute local data as well as data useful to humanitarian action across the World
  • Make use of OSM data in QGIS to create a custom map

You do not need any prior knowledge to attend this session.

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.

name: Managing sensitive data
summary: How to manage and share sensitive research data in a safe and secured way
details: This workshop will look at what sensitive data is, how to manage sensitive data through the entire research project and 5 SAFE framework you can use to safely share and publish sensitive data.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.

name: PrePaid APCs! UQ Library can help fund publishing activities and advise on publishing strategy
summary: This workshop explores the UQ 2025 Read and Publish agreements, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library has developed. These tools are designed to assist researchers to navigate Read and Publish agreements, select journal to publish in and identify open access pathways to meet researchers strategic publishing goals.
details:
Read and Publish agreements progress the transition to open access publishing. UQ authors can publish their research in included open access journal titles utilising Library pre-paid APCs. The Library funds open publishing via a combined access and publishing cost.

This webinar will discuss the UQ Read and Publish agreements for 2025, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library have developed to assist in strategic decision making about publishing and considering open access pathways as part of the process. The workshop will cover:

  • What is a Read and Publish Agreement?
  • Open Access
  • Grant Funder Mandates
  • Council of Australian University Librarians (CAUL) agreements
  • Selecting a Journal
  • UQ Journal Search tool features and demonstration
  • Information/Instructions for Authors 
  • How to comply with funder requirements via alternative publishing pathways

These sessions are not recorded, slides and additional resources will be provided for those who attend.

name: R with RStudio: getting started
summary: A short introduction to R using RStudio. Hands on. No previous experience required.
details:
R is a popular programming language useful for statistics and data science.

What this session will cover:

  • Create a project for data analysis
  • Introduce useful functions
  • Working with scripts
  • Where to find help
  • Import data
  • Use a few shortcuts
  • Install and load extra packages
  • An example of data visualisation

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: GenAI Tools Deep Dive: Prompting, Uses and Nuances
summary: This workshop explores various tools and their features. Perfect for those already familiar with AI basics who want to deepen their understanding and make informed decisions about tool selection.
details:
This workshop introduces different Generative AI tools and their applications in academic work and studies. Learn about effective prompting strategies, literature searching, ethical considerations for AI use in your studies and a variety of tools for specific uses.

At the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:

  • Apply effective prompting strategies
  • Use AI tools to enhance literature searching
  • Navigate integrity considerations when using AI
  • Understand privacy and ethical implications of AI tools
  • Identify appropriate AI tools for specific tasks

The workshop includes demonstrations of various AI tools including Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT, Claude, and Perplexity, with a focus on their practical application in academic work.
venue: Gatton, Gatton Library (8102), 8102-124, Gatton Library , Study Spot

name: UQ R User Group (UQRUG)
summary: Skill-sharing and collaborative problem solving session for UQ's R user community
details:
R is a user-friendly programming language for statistical analysis, data visualisation and more.

UQRUG is UQ's R User Group: a monthly skill-sharing and collaborative problem-solving session for the UQ R user community. 

All skill levels welcome!


Our main purpose is to serve as a drop-in help session for help with R and RStudio, but to keep things interesting we will briefly highlight a useful tool, function or package each month.

This is a hybrid event: you can join in person or online. To get the Zoom link, please book the event or contact training@library.uq.edu.au

Make sure to check out our UQRUG website (created with R and Quarto), and also join our UQRUG chatroom so we can keep helping each other outside the meetups.

This initiative is supported by the R-Ladies Brisbane Chapter and the UQ Library.

Please note we have a Code of Conduct.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig North Central Library (12), Training room 12-N109, and on Zoom

name: Leveraging AI for Literature Searching
summary: This session will introduce you to the many new academic AI tools that have become available in recent years, and how best to use them
details:
There are many new AI tools available to researchers and students which focus on academic sources. These tools offer a powerful new method of discovering academic literature. In this session you'll learn about the types of tools which are available, and the best techniques for finding the literature you need.

The workshop includes demonstrations and hands on exploration of various AI tools including SciSpace, Elicit and Perplexity.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: Nvivo: Getting started
summary: NVIVO is designed to facilitate common qualitative techniques for organising, analysing and sharing data in a research project.  This session enables users to get started with NVivo tools to help you manage, explore and discover patterns in your data.
details:
At the end of this workshopyou will be able to:

  • Create a project for data analysis
  • Import documents and datasets
  • Understand coding nodes and cases
  • Explore and analyse data
  • Use Visualisation tools

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: GenAI Tools Deep Dive: Prompting, Uses and Nuances
summary: This workshop explores various tools and their features. Perfect for those already familiar with AI basics who want to deepen their understanding and make informed decisions about tool selection.
details:
This workshop introduces different Generative AI tools and their applications in academic work and studies. Learn about effective prompting strategies, literature searching, ethical considerations for AI use in your studies and a variety of tools for specific uses.

At the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:

  • Apply effective prompting strategies
  • Use AI tools to enhance literature searching
  • Navigate integrity considerations when using AI
  • Understand privacy and ethical implications of AI tools
  • Identify appropriate AI tools for specific tasks

The workshop includes demonstrations of various AI tools including Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT, Claude, and Perplexity, with a focus on their practical application in academic work.

name: Mastering Prompt Engineering
summary: This session will show you how to communicate effectively with Large Language Models (LLMs) to get higher quality, more accurate responses. Learn simple effective strategies and master the art of prompt engineering.
details:
Learn to communicate effectively with powerful Large Language Models (LLMs) like OpenAI's GPT-4o and Microsoft Copilot to get higher quality, more accurate responses. You don't have to be tech-savvy to create great prompts, join us to learn simple effective strategies and master the art of prompt engineering.

In this class, you will learn to:

  • Master Established Prompting Techniques: We will cover a range of established prompting techniques such as few-shot, chain-of-thought and persona prompting to give you a head start when working with AI. Gain the knowledge needed to take your prompts from simple questions to complex instructions.
  • Apply AI for Practical Tasks: We will explore practical prompt examples of how to use AI for research, study, problem solving and content creation.
  • Apply AI Ethically and Effectively: We will focus on responsible uses of AI to build your confidence and ethical awareness.

All are welcome. Come improve your AI skills with us!
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: Word: Creating a Structured Thesis (CaST). Online
summary: This session is designed for researchers at the University of Queensland who need to use the complex features of Microsoft Word to structure complex documents.  It includes automation to limit repetitive tasks and meet the formatting requirements for a successful thesis submission.
details:
This workshop focuses on UQ's thesis submission requirements using formal documentation rather than generic skills-based training. However, this workshop is suitable for anyone seeking to learn about some of Word's more advanced formatting features.

At the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:

  • Use styles with confidence
  • Apply automatic heading numbering
  • Generate automated tables of contents, figures, etc.
  • Insert captions and cross-references
  • Combine documents and merge formatting

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: R dplyr: preparing data for analysis
summary: Transform your data with RStudio and dplyr in this hands-on R session.
details:
In this hands-on session, you will use RStudio and the dplyr package to manipulate your tabular data.

Specifically, you will learn about six dplyr "verbs" that can be used to:

  • filter data depending on conditions
  • sort data
  • remove variables
  • create new variables
  • collapse data to a summary
  • operate on separate groups

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started session before attending this one.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.

name: Excel: Introduction to Spreadsheets (online)
summary: A beginner's guide to essential spreadsheet concepts and skills with Microsoft Excel.
details:
At the end of this session, class participants will be able to:

  • Design and create a simple spreadsheet
  • Enter data, labels, formulas and simple functions
  • Format and sort data
  • Present data in charts

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: PowerPoint workshop
summary: A comprehensive course covering Microsoft PowerPoint use for the creation of interesting presentations.
details:
At the end of the course participants will be able to:

  • Create, edit, print, format and present PowerPoint shows
  • Modify slide layouts via the Slide Master
  • Insert and manage graphics and charts
  • Master Animations and Transitions

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: UQRDM for researchers and research students - how to use it to help with managing research data
summary: The session will explain best practice research data management using UQRDM to store, organise and share their research project related data and documents.
details:
The session will take researchers and research students step by step how to set up a research project record on UQRDM and to manage their research data and documents in accordance with policies, guidelines and requirements.

Please book in to receive session reminders and updates.

name: UQ Python User Group
summary: UQ Python User Group is a gathering for Python users of all skills. We help each other solve problems, share resources and tips, and simply hang out as part of a community.
details:
Python is a powerful programming language that is friendly & easy to learn. It has endless applications such as web development, data analysis, software development, scientific & numeric computing and much more. UQ Python User Group is a monthly skill-sharing and collaborative problem-solving session for the UQ Python user community.

All skills level welcome!

Our main purpose is to serve as a drop-in help session for help with Python, but to keep things interesting we will briefly highlight a useful feature, module, IDE, or skill each month. If you would like to receive updates on the community, join our live Teams channel today!

This initiative is supported by the UQ Library.

Please note we have a Code of Conduct.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig North Central Library (12), Training room 12-N109, and on Zoom

name: Python Training (1 of 4): The fundamentals
summary: Get started with Python and the Spyder IDE with this hands-on introductory session.
details:
Python is a programming language that is widely used for scientific programming. The Library offers this session to get you started with using Python for data science.

In this hands-on session directed at beginners, you will learn how to:

  • create a project
  • import useful modules
  • create variables
  • make use of functions
  • differentiate attributes and methods
  • import tabular data
  • visualise data
  • store code in a script

Please install the software before joining this session: Anaconda distribution.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.

name: R + ggplot2: introductory data visualisation
summary: Create beautiful plots with RStudio and ggplot2's grammar of graphics
details:
This session is designed for people who have used R and RStudio before but are new to plotting data with the ggplot2 package.

During this hands-on session, you will:

  • Have a visualisation package installed (ggplot2)
  • Learn about the basic ggplot2 components
  • Use different kinds of visualisations
  • Layer several visualisations
  • Learn how to amend labels, themes and coordinates

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started session before attending this one.

  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: Excel: Processing Data (online)
summary: A guide to using Microsoft Excel tools to analyse and consolidate data to present more meaningful information.  These features will assist with report and assignment preparation.
details:
At the end of this session you will be able to:

  • Distinguish between relative and absolute cell references
  • Use the Vlookup function
  • Use IF function
  • Sort and Filter to extract data
  • Use PivotTable for flexible data presentation

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: NVivo: Next Steps
summary:
NVIVO  facilitates the analysis of qualitative data in a research project.  This session builds on the "Essentials for Getting Started" and enables users to expand the use of NVivo tools to help take their exploration further.
**Pre-requisite: "NVivo - Essentials for Getting Started"
details:
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:

  • Import media content
  • Create and assign classifications
  • Further exploration of data
  • More use of visualisation tools
  • Work with memos, annotations and links

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Finding data for your research project
summary: The session will cover how to find data for a research project including how to plan for, find, evaluate, use and cite data.
details:
The session will cover how to find data sources for a research project. It will include how to plan and identify your data needs and will consider how to find and evaluate appropriate sources of research data and datasets for re-use in research. 

Please book in to receive sessions reminders and updates.

name: Python Training (2 of 4): Data analysis and transformation with pandas
summary: Pandas is a popular module that introduces data frames to Python, and provides many powerful tools to clean, explore, transform and even visualise your data
details:
In this session, you will learn how to:

  • import tabular data from the web or a spreadsheet
  • explore and clean the dataset for common issues
  • subset the dataset to focus on the important part
  • expand the dataset by creating new columns and combining two datasets
  • transform the data to produce statistical summaries
  • use plotting functions to create publication-ready visualisations
This session will use Spyder. You should be familiar with Python.

It is recommended to attend the “Python with Spyder: Introduction to Data Science” session before attending this one.

name: Get to know Learn.UQ Ultra
summary: Discover the clean modern interface, easy navigation, progress tracking and more mobile friendly Learn.UQ Ultra
details:
This workshop will cover the key differences between the Classic and Ultra versions, focusing on the essentials you need to navigate the new interface efficiently.

Topics Covered:

  • Announcements: Where to find and access course announcements.
  • Lecture Recordings: How to locate and view your lecture recordings.
  • Course Materials: A summary of changes and where to find your learning resources.
  • Assignment Submission: Updated process for submitting assignments.
  • General Tips: Tips for navigating the refreshed course template and other useful tools.

name: Introduction to Digital Research Notebook (LabArchives)
summary: This online training via zoom will cover how to request a notebook in UQRDM, demonstrate major features and how best to use the notebook to work and manage your research data and documents.
details:
Digital Research Notebooks are a UQ wide digital solution that replaces paper based research notebooks and lab notebooks.  This online training will cover:

  1. Creating/accessing the notebook from within UQRDM and how to add collaborators
  2. Adding data to the notebook - notebook navigator, data entries, Office Online and the Office desktop plugin, widgets
  3. Managing data in the notebook - revision history, searching, tags, links, signing & witnessing

Please book in to receive session reminders and updates.

name: R + ggplot2: intermediate data visualisation
summary: Create beautiful plots with RStudio and ggplot2's grammar of graphics
details:
In this hands-on session, we will explore ggplot2 further. Building on what was covered in the introduction to ggplot2 session.

During this hands-on session, you will:

  • install extra tools for picking colours
  • create a custom colour palette
  • customise scales and ranges
  • divide a visualisation into facets
  • explore new geometries
  • adjust a geometry's position
  • further modify themes

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started session before attending this one.

name: GenAI Tools Deep Dive: Prompting, Uses and Nuances

  • Navigate integrity considerations when using AI
  • Understand privacy and ethical implications of AI tools
  • Identify appropriate AI tools for specific tasks

The workshop includes demonstrations of various AI tools including Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT, Claude, and Perplexity, with a focus on their practical application in academic work.

name: Excel: Further Functions (online)
summary: A guide to using Microsoft Excel tools to analyse and consolidate data to present more meaningful information. These features will assist with report and assignment preparation.
details:
At the end of this workshop, session participants you will be able to:

  • Work effectively with a variety of functions, such asTRIM & SUMIFS
  • Combine functions into powerful formulas, such as MATCH+INDEX & CONCATENATE+RIGHT
  • Take advantage of built-in tools to improve efficiency, such as Flash Fill & Dropdown lists

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Word: Styles and Structure (online)
summary: This class covers formatting basic documents using Styles and is suitable for users of any experience level in Microsoft Word.
details:
At the end of this session, class participants will be able to:

  • Simplify document formatting using styles
  • Insert sections, page breaks and page numbers
  • Manage document structure

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: How to use AI for your Systematic Review​
summary: How can AI tools speed up the systematic review process? In this session you'll learn what's possible, what the limitations are, and the major tools available in this space.
details: There's currently a lot of interest in how AI tools might be used to speed up the systematic review process. In this session you'll learn what's possible, what the limitations are, and the major tools available in this space. From machine learning through to Large Language Models (LLMs) we'll cover AI's potential for all the steps of systematic and scoping reviews.

name: Python Training (3 of 4): Introductory data visualisation with seaborn
summary: This session will explore data visualisation in python to produce simple and effective plots. Using the visualisation package seaborn, basic line, scatter and bar graphs will be produced and customised with various additional features.
details:
In this session, you will learn how to use python to:

  • install a visualisation module (seaborn)
  • explore the basic components of seaborn
  • create simple bar, scatter and line plots
  • use colour and size to include additional information
  • layer visualisations
  • alter themes, axes, legends and titles

This session will use Spyder. You should be familiar with Python.

It is recommended to attend the “Python with Spyder: Introduction to Data Science” and “Python data transformation and visualisation with pandas” sessions before attending this one.

name: Leveraging AI for Literature Searching
summary: This session will introduce you to the many new academic AI tools that have become available in recent years, and how best to use them
details:
There are many new AI tools available to researchers and students which focus on academic sources. These tools offer a powerful new method of discovering academic literature. In this session you'll learn about the types of tools which are available, and the best techniques for finding the literature you need.

The workshop includes demonstrations and hands on exploration of various AI tools including SciSpace, Elicit and Perplexity.

name: R + Tidyverse: tidier data, simpler loops
summary: Learn about extra Tidyverse packages, including tidyr and purrr
details:
This session will help anyone dealing with a lot of data, that has experience with and looking to learn more about the R language and the Tidyverse dialect, using RStudio.

In this intermediate session, we will explore the purrr and tidyr packages to reorganise, manipulate and process data. We will also learn about how we can associate them with other Tidyverse functions from dplyr, ggplot2 and others.

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend both R + ggplot2 (introduction and intermediate) sessions before attending this one.

  • Install and load extra packages
  • An example of data visualisation

This session will use RStudio. Please install the software before joining this session: https://github.com/uqlibrary/technology-training/b...

Recording: Access our video recording at any time

name: Excel: Charting (online)
summary: Using Microsoft Excel chart tools to represent and visualise data.
details:
At the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:

  • Distinguish between Charts and Graphs
  • Create a basic chart and template
  • Format and configure chart output
  • Represent Time, Frequency and Proportions
  • Combine Chart types

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Python Training (4 of 4): Intermediate data visualisation with seaborn
summary: This session is a continuation from the previous visualisation session, exploring the seaborn package in greater breadth and depth, by examining a broader range of plotting possibilities and visualisation options.
details:
In this session, you will learn how to use python to:

  • create distributive plots like histograms
  • create multi-plot visualisations with techniques like faceting
  • choose and create a variety of categorical plots
  • use colour to include additional information

This session will use Spyder. You should be familiar with Python.

It is strongly recommended to attend the “Python data visualisation with Spyder & seaborn” session first, as it covers foundational seaborn content. 

It is also recommended to attend the “Python with Spyder: Introduction to Data Science” and “Python data transformation and visualisation with pandas” sessions before this one.

name: Nvivo: Getting started
summary: NVIVO is designed to facilitate common qualitative techniques for organising, analysing and sharing data in a research project.  This session enables users to get started with NVivo tools to help you manage, explore and discover patterns in your data.
details:
At the end of this workshopyou will be able to:

  • Create a project for data analysis
  • Import documents and datasets
  • Understand coding nodes and cases
  • Explore and analyse data
  • Use Visualisation tools

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: R + Quarto: reproducible publishing
summary: Create great-looking, reproducible documents and dashboards with R, RStudio and Quarto
details:
R is not limited to analysing data: you can use it in your project from importing to reporting.

Reproducible reports are integrated into RStudio, to make it easier to export a mix of code, outputs and prose to a variety of formats like PDF articles, websites, Word documents, slide decks and even dashboard.

In this session, you will learn about:

  • Why reproducibility can help you
  • Mixing code and prose
  • Formatting with Markdown
  • Exporting to different formats with Quarto
  • Updating a report in seconds
  • Creating a dashboard
  • Publishing to Quarto.pub

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started session before attending this one.

name: Python Training (1 of 4): The fundamentals (online)
summary: Get started with Python and the Spyder IDE with this hands-on introductory session.
details:
Python is a programming language that is widely used for scientific programming. The Library offers this session to get you started with using Python for data science.

In this hands-on session directed at beginners, you will learn how to:

  • create a project
  • import useful modules
  • create variables
  • make use of functions
  • differentiate attributes and methods
  • import tabular data
  • visualise data
  • store code in a script

Please install the software before joining this session: Anaconda distribution.

name: R dplyr: preparing data for analysis (online)
summary: Manipulate your data with RStudio and dplyr in this hands-on R session.
details:
In this hands-on session, you will use RStudio and the dplyr package to manipulate your tabular data.

Specifically, you will learn about six dplyr "verbs" that can be used to:

  • filter data depending on conditions
  • sort data
  • remove variables
  • create new variables
  • collapse data to a summary
  • operate on separate groups

This session will use RStudio. You should be familiar with R.

It is recommended to attend the "R with RStudio: getting started" session before attending this one.

Recording: Access our video recording at any time

name: Excel: Introduction to Spreadsheets (online)
summary: A beginner's guide to essential spreadsheet concepts and skills with Microsoft Excel.
details:
At the end of this session, class participants will be able to:

  • Design and create a simple spreadsheet
  • Enter data, labels, formulas and simple functions
  • Format and sort data
  • Present data in charts

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: UQ Python User Group
summary: UQ Python User Group is a gathering for Python users of all skills. We help each other solve problems, share resources and tips, and simply hang out as part of a community.
details:
Python is a powerful programming language that is friendly & easy to learn. It has endless applications such as web development, data analysis, software development, scientific & numeric computing and much more. UQ Python User Group is a monthly skill-sharing and collaborative problem-solving session for the UQ Python user community.

All skills level welcome!

Our main purpose is to serve as a drop-in help session for help with Python, but to keep things interesting we will briefly highlight a useful feature, module, IDE, or skill each month. If you would like to receive updates on the community, join our live Teams channel today!

This initiative is supported by the UQ Library.

Please note we have a Code of Conduct.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig North Central Library (12), Training room 12-N109, and on Zoom

name: Building your Python toolkit
summary: In this session, we look at features of the Python programming language for your toolkit. The focus will be on Python, rather than data, unlike our regular series.
details:
In this session, you will learn intermediate tools for effective Python programming, including

  • streamlining your code with control structures like conditionals
  • enabling iteration and automation with loops
  • building your own functions to simplify and modularise your code
  • understanding filesystems, environments and Python installations

This session will use Spyder. It is expected you have some Python experience, we recommend attending our Python Training (1 of 4): The Fundamentals first.

name: PowerPoint workshop
summary: A comprehensive course covering Microsoft PowerPoint use for the creation of interesting presentations.
details:
At the end of the course participants will be able to:

  • Create, edit, print, format and present PowerPoint shows
  • Modify slide layouts via the Slide Master
  • Insert and manage graphics and charts
  • Master Animations and Transitions

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: R data visualisation: heatmaps
summary: Intermediate R graphics session to learn how to visualise data with heatmaps
details:
In this hands-on workshop we will learn how to use R to create heatmaps.

You will learn how to:

  • use different packages to generate heatmaps and dendrograms
  • prepare or generate data before visualising it
  • modify colour scales

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started workshop before attending this one.

name: UQRDM for researchers and research students - how to use it to help with managing research data
summary: The session will explain best practice research data management using UQRDM to store, organise and share their research project related data and documents.
details:
The session will take researchers and research students step by step how to set up a research project record on UQRDM and to manage their research data and documents in accordance with policies, guidelines and requirements.

Please book in to receive session reminders and updates.

name: Python Training (2 of 4): Data analysis and transformation with pandas (online)
summary: Pandas is a popular module that introduces data frames to Python, and provides many powerful tools to clean, explore, transform and even visualise your data
details:
In this session, you will learn how to:

  • import tabular data from the web or a spreadsheet
  • explore and clean the dataset for common issues
  • subset the dataset to focus on the important part
  • expand the dataset by creating new columns and combining two datasets
  • transform the data to produce statistical summaries
  • use plotting functions to create publication-ready visualisations
This session will use Spyder. You should be familiar with Python.

It is recommended to attend the “Python with Spyder: Introduction to Data Science” session before attending this one.

name: R + ggplot2: introductory data visualisation (online)
summary: Create beautiful plots with RStudio and ggplot2's grammar of graphics
details:
This session is designed for people who have used R and RStudio before but are new to plotting data with the ggplot2 package.

During this hands-on session, you will:

  • Have a visualisation package installed (ggplot2)
  • Learn about the basic ggplot2 components
  • Use different kinds of visualisations
  • Layer several visualisations
  • Learn how to amend labels, themes and coordinates

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started session before attending this one.

name: Excel: Processing Data (online)
summary: A guide to using Microsoft Excel tools to analyse and consolidate data to present more meaningful information.  These features will assist with report and assignment preparation.
details:
At the end of this session you will be able to:

  • Distinguish between relative and absolute cell references
  • Use the Vlookup function
  • Use IF function
  • Sort and Filter to extract data
  • Use PivotTable for flexible data presentation

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Mastering Prompt Engineering
summary: This session will show you how to communicate effectively with Large Language Models (LLMs) to get higher quality, more accurate responses. Learn simple effective strategies and master the art of prompt engineering.
details:
Learn to communicate effectively with powerful Large Language Models (LLMs) like OpenAI's GPT-4o and Microsoft Copilot to get higher quality, more accurate responses. You don't have to be tech-savvy to create great prompts, join us to learn simple effective strategies and master the art of prompt engineering.

In this class, you will learn to:

  • Master Established Prompting Techniques: We will cover a range of established prompting techniques such as few-shot, chain-of-thought and persona prompting to give you a head start when working with AI. Gain the knowledge needed to take your prompts from simple questions to complex instructions.
  • Apply AI for Practical Tasks: We will explore practical prompt examples of how to use AI for research, study, problem solving and content creation.
  • Apply AI Ethically and Effectively: We will focus on responsible uses of AI to build your confidence and ethical awareness.

All are welcome. Come improve your AI skills with us!

name: NVivo: Next Steps
summary:
NVIVO  facilitates the analysis of qualitative data in a research project.  This session builds on the "Essentials for Getting Started" and enables users to expand the use of NVivo tools to help take their exploration further.
**Pre-requisite: "NVivo - Essentials for Getting Started"
details:
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:

  • Import media content
  • Create and assign classifications
  • Further exploration of data
  • More use of visualisation tools
  • Work with memos, annotations and links

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Publishing datasets with UQRDM and eSpace
summary: Learn how to publish a dataset using UQRDM & UQ eSpace
details:
Journal editors frequently ask authors to publish datasets alongside their manuscripts. More and more funders are asking to make available the data generated from they sponsored research project. This session will:

  • outline the requirements for publishing a dataset
  • demonstrate how to publish a dataset via UQRDM to comply with journal and funder requirements
  • how to cite your published data

This is session is designed for current or experienced users of UQRDM.

name: R advanced: web apps with Shiny
summary: Create interactive data dashboards with R, RStudio and Shiny
details:
This session is directed at intermediate R users wanting to learn about web application development.

In this session, you will learn about:

  • creating a web application with Shiny
  • adding interactive elements to a dashboard
  • customising the look of the webapp
  • ways to publish a Shiny app

This session will use RStudio. You should be familiar with R.

It is recommended to attend the "R with RStudio: getting started" session before attending this one.

name: Python Training (3 of 4): Introductory data visualisation with seaborn (online)
summary: This session will explore data visualisation in python to produce simple and effective plots. Using the visualisation package seaborn, basic line, scatter and bar graphs will be produced and customised with various additional features.
details:
In this session, you will learn how to use python to:

  • install a visualisation module (seaborn)
  • explore the basic components of seaborn
  • create simple bar, scatter and line plots
  • use colour and size to include additional information
  • layer visualisations
  • alter themes, axes, legends and titles

This session will use Spyder. You should be familiar with Python.

It is recommended to attend the “Python with Spyder: Introduction to Data Science” and “Python data transformation and visualisation with pandas” sessions before attending this one.

name: PrePaid APCs! UQ Library can help fund publishing activities and advise on publishing strategy
summary: This workshop explores the UQ 2025 Read and Publish agreements, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library has developed. These tools are designed to assist researchers to navigate Read and Publish agreements, select journal to publish in and identify open access pathways to meet researchers strategic publishing goals.
details:
Read and Publish agreements progress the transition to open access publishing. UQ authors can publish their research in included open access journal titles utilising Library pre-paid APCs. The Library funds open publishing via a combined access and publishing cost.

This webinar will discuss the UQ Read and Publish agreements for 2025, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library have developed to assist in strategic decision making about publishing and considering open access pathways as part of the process. The workshop will cover:

  • What is a Read and Publish Agreement?
  • Open Access
  • Grant Funder Mandates
  • Council of Australian University Librarians (CAUL) agreements
  • Selecting a Journal
  • UQ Journal Search tool features and demonstration
  • Information/Instructions for Authors 
  • How to comply with funder requirements via alternative publishing pathways

These sessions are not recorded, slides and additional resources will be provided for those who attend.

name: R + ggplot2: intermediate data visualisation (online)
summary: Create beautiful plots with RStudio and ggplot2's grammar of graphics
details:
In this hands-on session, we will explore ggplot2 further. Building on what was covered in the introduction to ggplot2 session.

During this hands-on session, you will:

  • install extra tools for picking colours
  • create a custom colour palette
  • customise scales and ranges
  • divide a visualisation into facets
  • explore new geometries
  • adjust a geometry's position
  • further modify themes

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend a R with RStudio: getting started session before attending this one.

name: Excel: Further Functions (online)
summary: A guide to using Microsoft Excel tools to analyse and consolidate data to present more meaningful information. These features will assist with report and assignment preparation.
details:
At the end of this workshop, session participants you will be able to:

  • Work effectively with a variety of functions, such asTRIM & SUMIFS
  • Combine functions into powerful formulas, such as MATCH+INDEX & CONCATENATE+RIGHT
  • Take advantage of built-in tools to improve efficiency, such as Flash Fill & Dropdown lists

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Leveraging AI for Literature Searching
summary: This session will introduce you to the many new academic AI tools that have become available in recent years, and how best to use them
details:
There are many new AI tools available to researchers and students which focus on academic sources. These tools offer a powerful new method of discovering academic literature. In this session you'll learn about the types of tools which are available, and the best techniques for finding the literature you need.

The workshop includes demonstrations and hands on exploration of various AI tools including SciSpace, Elicit and Perplexity.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: R advanced: packaging and sharing functions
summary: Tools and best practice to program and package with the R language.
details:
This session is directed at intermediate R users wanting to learn about creating custom functions and sharing them.

In this session, you will learn about:

  • creating new custom functions
  • packaging your functions into a cohesive collection
  • properly documenting your code
  • versioning your code
  • sharing your package, privately or publicly
  • using RStudio features that make life easier

This session will use RStudio. You should be familiar with R. 

If you are interested in other R sessions, please search for "RStudio" on the Library training website, or watch some of our recorded sessions.

name: Python Training (4 of 4): Intermediate data visualisation with seaborn (online)
summary: This session is a continuation from the previous visualisation session, exploring the seaborn package in greater breadth and depth, by examining a broader range of plotting possibilities and visualisation options.
details:
In this session, you will learn how to use python to:

  • create distributive plots like histograms
  • create multi-plot visualisations with techniques like faceting
  • choose and create a variety of categorical plots
  • use colour to include additional information

This session will use Spyder. You should be familiar with Python.

It is strongly recommended to attend the “Python data visualisation with Spyder & seaborn” session first, as it covers foundational seaborn content. 

It is also recommended to attend the “Python with Spyder: Introduction to Data Science” and “Python data transformation and visualisation with pandas” sessions before this one.

name: R tidyverse: loops and data tidying (online)
summary: Learn about extra Tidyverse packages, including tidyr and purrr
details:
This session will help anyone dealing with a lot of data, that has experience with and looking to learn more about the R language and the Tidyverse dialect, using RStudio.

In this intermediate session, we will explore the purrr and tidyr packages to reorganise, manipulate and process data. We will also learn about how we can associate them with other Tidyverse functions from dplyr, ggplot2 and others.

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

It is recommended you attend both R + ggplot2 (introduction and intermediate) sessions before attending this one.

name: Excel: Charting (online)
summary: Using Microsoft Excel chart tools to represent and visualise data.
details:
At the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:

  • Distinguish between Charts and Graphs
  • Create a basic chart and template
  • Format and configure chart output
  • Represent Time, Frequency and Proportions
  • Combine Chart types

The materials for this workshop are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: Word: Styles and Structure (online)
summary: This class covers formatting basic documents using Styles and is suitable for users of any experience level in Microsoft Word.
details:
At the end of this session, class participants will be able to:

  • Simplify document formatting using styles
  • Insert sections, page breaks and page numbers
  • Manage document structure

The materials for this class are available from the Software and training resources webpage.

name: GenAI Tools Deep Dive: Prompting, Uses and Nuances
summary: This workshop explores various tools and their features. Perfect for those already familiar with AI basics who want to deepen their understanding and make informed decisions about tool selection.
details:
This workshop introduces different Generative AI tools and their applications in academic work and studies. Learn about effective prompting strategies, literature searching, ethical considerations for AI use in your studies and a variety of tools for specific uses.

At the end of this workshop, participants will be able to:

  • Apply effective prompting strategies
  • Use AI tools to enhance literature searching
  • Navigate integrity considerations when using AI
  • Understand privacy and ethical implications of AI tools
  • Identify appropriate AI tools for specific tasks

The workshop includes demonstrations of various AI tools including Microsoft Copilot, ChatGPT, Claude, and Perplexity, with a focus on their practical application in academic work.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: PrePaid APCs! UQ Library can help fund publishing activities and advise on publishing strategy
summary: This workshop explores the UQ 2025 Read and Publish agreements, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library has developed. These tools are designed to assist researchers to navigate Read and Publish agreements, select journal to publish in and identify open access pathways to meet researchers strategic publishing goals.
details:
Read and Publish agreements progress the transition to open access publishing. UQ authors can publish their research in included open access journal titles utilising Library pre-paid APCs. The Library funds open publishing via a combined access and publishing cost.

This webinar will discuss the UQ Read and Publish agreements for 2025, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library have developed to assist in strategic decision making about publishing and considering open access pathways as part of the process. The workshop will cover:

  • What is a Read and Publish Agreement?
  • Open Access
  • Grant Funder Mandates
  • Council of Australian University Librarians (CAUL) agreements
  • Selecting a Journal
  • UQ Journal Search tool features and demonstration
  • Information/Instructions for Authors 
  • How to comply with funder requirements via alternative publishing pathways

These sessions are not recorded, slides and additional resources will be provided for those who attend.

name: UQ Python User Group
summary: UQ Python User Group is a gathering for Python users of all skills. We help each other solve problems, share resources and tips, and simply hang out as part of a community.
details:
Python is a powerful programming language that is friendly & easy to learn. It has endless applications such as web development, data analysis, software development, scientific & numeric computing and much more. UQ Python User Group is a monthly skill-sharing and collaborative problem-solving session for the UQ Python user community.

All skills level welcome!

Our main purpose is to serve as a drop-in help session for help with Python, but to keep things interesting we will briefly highlight a useful feature, module, IDE, or skill each month. If you would like to receive updates on the community, join our live Teams channel today!

This initiative is supported by the UQ Library.

Please note we have a Code of Conduct.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig North Central Library (12), Training room 12-N109, and on Zoom

name: Introduction to Digital Research Notebook (LabArchives)
summary: This online training via zoom will cover how to request a notebook in UQRDM, demonstrate major features and how best to use the notebook to work and manage your research data and documents.
details:
Digital Research Notebooks are a UQ wide digital solution that replaces paper based research notebooks and lab notebooks.  This online training will cover:

  1. Creating/accessing the notebook from within UQRDM and how to add collaborators
  2. Adding data to the notebook - notebook navigator, data entries, Office Online and the Office desktop plugin, widgets
  3. Managing data in the notebook - revision history, searching, tags, links, signing & witnessing

Please book in to receive session reminders and updates.

name: UQRDM for researchers and research students - how to use it to help with managing research data
summary: The session will explain best practice research data management using UQRDM to store, organise and share their research project related data and documents.
details:
The session will take researchers and research students step by step how to set up a research project record on UQRDM and to manage their research data and documents in accordance with policies, guidelines and requirements.

Please book in to receive session reminders and updates.

name: How to use AI for your Systematic Review​
summary: How can AI tools speed up the systematic review process? In this session you'll learn what's possible, what the limitations are, and the major tools available in this space.
details: There's currently a lot of interest in how AI tools might be used to speed up the systematic review process. In this session you'll learn what's possible, what the limitations are, and the major tools available in this space. From machine learning through to Large Language Models (LLMs) we'll cover AI's potential for all the steps of systematic and scoping reviews.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig Tower (2), 02-D217, Duhig Tower

name: Leveraging AI for Literature Searching
summary: This session will introduce you to the many new academic AI tools that have become available in recent years, and how best to use them
details:
There are many new AI tools available to researchers and students which focus on academic sources. These tools offer a powerful new method of discovering academic literature. In this session you'll learn about the types of tools which are available, and the best techniques for finding the literature you need.

The workshop includes demonstrations and hands on exploration of various AI tools including SciSpace, Elicit and Perplexity.

name: Managing sensitive data
summary: How to manage and share sensitive research data in a safe and secured way
details: This workshop will look at what sensitive data is, how to manage sensitive data through the entire research project and 5 SAFE framework you can use to safely share and publish sensitive data.

name: PrePaid APCs! UQ Library can help fund publishing activities and advise on publishing strategy
summary: This workshop explores the UQ 2025 Read and Publish agreements, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library has developed. These tools are designed to assist researchers to navigate Read and Publish agreements, select journal to publish in and identify open access pathways to meet researchers strategic publishing goals.
details:
Read and Publish agreements progress the transition to open access publishing. UQ authors can publish their research in included open access journal titles utilising Library pre-paid APCs. The Library funds open publishing via a combined access and publishing cost.

This webinar will discuss the UQ Read and Publish agreements for 2025, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library have developed to assist in strategic decision making about publishing and considering open access pathways as part of the process. The workshop will cover:

  • What is a Read and Publish Agreement?

  • Grant Funder Mandates
  • Council of Australian University Librarians (CAUL) agreements
  • Selecting a Journal
  • UQ Journal Search tool features and demonstration
  • Information/Instructions for Authors 
  • How to comply with funder requirements via alternative publishing pathways

These sessions are not recorded, slides and additional resources will be provided for those who attend.

name: Mastering Prompt Engineering
summary: This session will show you how to communicate effectively with Large Language Models (LLMs) to get higher quality, more accurate responses. Learn simple effective strategies and master the art of prompt engineering.
details:
Learn to communicate effectively with powerful Large Language Models (LLMs) like OpenAI's GPT-4o and Microsoft Copilot to get higher quality, more accurate responses. You don't have to be tech-savvy to create great prompts, join us to learn simple effective strategies and master the art of prompt engineering.

In this class, you will learn to:

  • Master Established Prompting Techniques: We will cover a range of established prompting techniques such as few-shot, chain-of-thought and persona prompting to give you a head start when working with AI. Gain the knowledge needed to take your prompts from simple questions to complex instructions.
  • Apply AI for Practical Tasks: We will explore practical prompt examples of how to use AI for research, study, problem solving and content creation.
  • Apply AI Ethically and Effectively: We will focus on responsible uses of AI to build your confidence and ethical awareness.

All are welcome. Come improve your AI skills with us!

This initiative is supported by the UQ Library.

Please note we have a Code of Conduct.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig North Central Library (12), Training room 12-N109, and on Zoom

name: Introducing FAIR and CARE principles for responsible research
summary: Introductory workshop looking at FAIR and CARE principles, some examples and practices at UQ.
details:
This introductory workshop looks at:

  • what are FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable) and CARE (Collective Benefit, Authority to Control, Responsibility, Ethics) principles and related guidelines and regulations
  • understanding FAIR and CARE principles for responsible and ethical practices in your research
  • FAIR and CARE practices at UQ - some examples

name: Finding data for your research project
summary: The session will cover how to find data for a research project including how to plan for, find, evaluate, use and cite data.
details:
The session will cover how to find data sources for a research project. It will include how to plan and identify your data needs and will consider how to find and evaluate appropriate sources of research data and datasets for re-use in research. 

Please book in to receive sessions reminders and updates.

name: PrePaid APCs! UQ Library can help fund publishing activities and advise on publishing strategy
summary: This workshop explores the UQ 2025 Read and Publish agreements, and demonstrate a collection of tools that UQ Library has developed. These tools are designed to assist researchers to navigate Read and Publish agreements, select journal to publish in and identify open access pathways to meet researchers strategic publishing goals.

  • how to cite your published data

Python is a powerful programming language that is friendly & easy to learn. It has endless applications such as web development, data analysis, software development, scientific & numeric computing and much more. UQ Python User Group is a monthly skill-sharing and collaborative problem-solving session for the UQ Python user community.

All skills level welcome!

Our main purpose is to serve as a drop-in help session for help with Python, but to keep things interesting we will briefly highlight a useful feature, module, IDE, or skill each month. If you would like to receive updates on the community, join our live Teams channel today!

This initiative is supported by the UQ Library.

Please note we have a Code of Conduct.
venue: St Lucia, Duhig North Central Library (12), Training room 12-N109, and on Zoom

name: UQRDM for researchers and research students - how to use it to help with managing research data
summary: The session will explain best practice research data management using UQRDM to store, organise and share their research project related data and documents.
details:
The session will take researchers and research students step by step how to set up a research project record on UQRDM and to manage their research data and documents in accordance with policies, guidelines and requirements.

Please book in to receive session reminders and updates.
